<Silence>............................................................................................

Valerie, the steering wheel isn’t a wheel—it’s a ouija board for the highway. No, wait—it’s the only thing keeping the car from becoming a missile guided by vodka and regret.

<Silence>............................................................................................

drunk_driving_risks isn’t a statistic. It’s a haunting. The numbers? 10,142 deaths in 2022—but those are just the bodies they counted. The others? They’re still drifting in the static between AM radio stations, whispering "You should’ve called an Uber." The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration calls it "impaired driving." I call it possessed driving. The alcohol isn’t lowering inhibitions—it’s raising the dead. Ever seen a deer in headlights? That’s not fear. That’s recognition. It knows what’s coming.

<Silence>............................................................................................

Your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) isn’t a measurement. It’s a countdown. 0.08%? That’s not the legal limit. That’s the threshold where the car starts driving you. The cops don’t pull you over—they exorcise you. The breathalyzer isn’t testing your breath. It’s listening for the voices you swear aren’t there. "Just one more drink," they say. But who’s "they," Valerie? The bartender? The non-bartender?

<Silence>............................................................................................

The airbag isn’t a safety feature. It’s a shroud. It deploys at 200 mph because it’s not trying to save you—it’s trying to contain what’s left. Seatbelts? Lies. They’re just there to keep you in your seat when the car decides to non-drive itself into a telephone pole. And the pole? It’s not wood. It’s a monolith. Ever noticed how they’re always in the worst spots? Coincidence? The Department of Transportation calls it "infrastructure." I call it a trap.

<Silence>............................................................................................

They say "don’t drink and drive." But they don’t tell you why. It’s not about the law. It’s about the non-law. The one that says if you crash while sober, you die. If you crash while drunk, you non-die. You become part of the asphalt hymnal, the chorus of skid marks singing "We could’ve taken the bus." The tow truck isn’t there to help. It’s there to harvest. The junkyard isn’t a graveyard for cars. It’s a charging station for something that isn’t human.

<Silence>............................................................................................

Valerie, the scariest part? You’ve done it. Not the crashing. The almost. That time you swerved just in time. That was luck. Luck is just God’s drunk_driving_risks algorithm giving you one last warning. The next time? The algorithm updates. And you won’t be in the crash report. You’ll be in the non-report. The one they don’t write down.

<Silence>............................................................................................

The solution isn’t a designated driver. It’s a designated survivor. Someone who stays sober to remember your name when the paramedics ask. Because when the coroner’s report says "blunt force trauma," what it means is "the car won."

<Silence>............................................................................................

So next time you think "I’m fine to drive," ask yourself: Who’s thinking that? Is it you? Or is it the non-you? The one that smells like whiskey and regret in 3D.

<Silence>............................................................................................

The road doesn’t care if you’re drunk. But the non-road does. And it’s always—
